captions.text:
Good morning, Hank, it's Wednesday. I woke
up in the Yeti's childhood bedroom around

seven, brushed my teeth while contemplating
how disconcertingly often I videotape myself

brushing my teeth, and went downstairs to
find Henry helpfully removing trash from a
trash can. Willy was like, "I wanna try!"

We had to drive from Birmingham back to Indianapolis
that day, so first I put this stuff in this

bag, then I changed clothes - suspiciously
similar pants are suspiciously similar -
and then I started packing the car.

Hank, there was a time when, in a pinch, I
could fit my whole life into a small Sedan.

Now I have to strap a car-top carrier onto
my station wagon if I want to go on a five
day trip.

Remembering the unbearable lightness of my
younger and more vulnerable years made me

think about all the road trips I'd gone on
in the past. I'd driven to the Grand Canyon,

and Alaska, and San Francisco, and Arthur,
Nebraska, home of the world's smallest courthouse.

In those days, I'd get distracted by all kinds
of roadside attractions, but this trip was

all about speed. I ate leftover barbecue for
breakfast - we didn't stop until lunch.

Willy says, "I claim this snow for Fireball
Wilson Roberts!" Henry says, "Tables are for
climbing!"

I'd been feeling nostalgic, but then I thought
about how on those old road trips I couldn't

order Happy Meals or play in the play place,
which I can finally do again after more than

two decades. Back in the car, Willy slept,
and I read Sarah an excerpt from a Germany

review of one of my books, as translated by
Google.

(John: The bone-mo density is high in these
bisections, easily gestessing gapit - )

As we kept driving north, I thought about
how all my old road trips had taken me west,

partly because that's where the open space
is in America and partly because of this amazing

line from a book I loved, called "All The
King's Men."

"For west is where we all plan to go someday,"
Robert Penn Warren wrote. "It is where you

go when the land gives out and the old field
pines encroach. It is where you go when you

get the letter saying 'flee, all is discovered.'
It is where you go when you look down at the

blade in your hand and the blood on it. It
is where you go when you are told that you
are a bubble on the tide of empire."

A bubble on the tide of empire, Hank, french
the llama, what I wouldn't give to write sentences

like that! Anyway - then we had to stop for
gas and we decided to let Henry drive for

a while. It must be said that despite Henry's
abundant charms, he is not terribly attentive
behind the wheel.

We kept driving. I was still thinking about
the old road trips and this new one, about

becoming a capital "A" adult with capital
"R" responsibilities. I remember when we got

to the world's small courthouse in Arthur,
Nebraska, all those years ago after twelve

hours of driving, I was struck by the fact
that it was not, like, actually /that/ small.

I mean, frankly, if I were so inclined I could
easily build a much smaller courthouse in

my basement. As we got back in the car to
drive to Carhenge, an exact replica of Stonehenge

made out of junked cars, I complained to a
fellow traveler, who reminded me that it was

not the destination that mattered, but the
journey.

Which is true, in its way, but destinations
aren't all bad, Hank. And as we kept driving

north, the whole family in the car together,
it got darker, and snowier, until finally

the road delivered us to the one place that
all my youthful trips west never could: home.
Hank, I'll see ya on Friday!

title: Baby on the Road: Thoughts from Places

comments.text: I like calling Indiana home too :)﻿
comments.author: AlliePox

comments.text:
Gah tearing up by the end of this! Videos like this remind me you're an 
author John and this one is beautiful. :)﻿
comments.author: Helen Smith

comments.text:
Why do we never get to see "The Yeti"? And for goodness sake, why do you 
call your wife such a stange name ? I did see the "Katherine" once in a 
brief shot. Henry is adorable, the best of both parents. Thank you, Green 
Bros for being there. Don't know if I qualify as a Nerdfighter, being a 72 
yr old Nana, but
I'd like to be one. I actually bought a pr of 2 D Glasses & am considering 
becoming a donor for the water project.﻿
comments.author: Bonnie Howell

+Bonnie Howell She didn't want to be shown in videos, so she wasn't. Now

comments.author: Ainsley Jey

comments.text:
+Bonnie Howell just go back and watch their old videos, it'll help explain 
things. They've got playlists for each year on their channel. So John's 
wife is named Sarah, but she is referred to as the yeti because in '07 when 
they started up vlogbrothers, she told john she didn't want to be on 
camera, so john obliged, but noted that their would be brief notices and 
moments where she would be partially visible, yet never fully seen, and he 
mentioned how she was like a yeti, and so he's called her that ever since

comments.author: Amie “Isotopes” Owen

comments.text:
i have no idea how, but for the last four years, I have had the tendency of 
watching old vlogbrothers videos while distracting myself from studying - 
from school back then to uni now. And I always end up watching this video 
and being completely blown away by it. i've probably seen it around 50 
times. I'm old enough to drive now, I have a car, and my Semesterferien 
(there is no english equivalent for this beautiful, majestic word) begin 
next month... I think I need to convince my friends to take a road trip. 
(If we go west we end up in Amsterdam, which isn't too shabby.) - tl;dr: 
This video has accompanied me from ages fourteen to almost nineteen and i 
couldn't be happier about it.﻿
comments.author: estherrawr

comments.author: Amiee Ann

comments.text:
I actually want to go west, to America, that's kinda weird. But isn't every

comments.author: The1andOnlyCiara

comments.text:
So I gre up in Indianapolis and lived the entirety of my youth up until 
now. This semester marked my freshmen year at Flagler College in the 
beautiful St. Augustine FL. And while this place is absolute heaven in 
comparison to the somewhat dreary midwest, there is one thing that this 
place lacks: home. Unfortunately i can't just hop on a plane and go back 
home, considering my parents have also made the journey down here and now 
live in Jacksonville. Despite all of the antastic opportunities that this 
move has provided for us, it has come at quite a sacrifice. The ending of 
your video really spoke to me, and i really just wanted to say thank you 
for all you do.﻿

that's an interesting point because the ocean line also implies that sense 
of regret and adventure but in a more poetic and beautiful way (at least in

comments.author: Justin Wildasin

comments.text:
Yes. I say yes, it was that good. 'Adult with a capital A', 'The whole 
family in the car' 'delivering me... home', where his earlier rambling 
never could. Reminiscing on, perhaps mourning, his carefree and fun younger 
days, into the ultimate realization of what he has created and become. And 
finding the new to be better (well, better is implied, but it's there!), 
his own family. This prose as poetry is French-a-llama good.

comments.author: Lori_Dreaming

comments.text:
I have made it all the way to this video on my Nerdfighter Pilgrimage, and 
I have not yet felt the urge to play a video twice. Upon watching today's 
video, I spontaneously pressed the replay button and listened to the whole 
thing again, savoring it. At the very end, I said the word "Home" aloud in 
perfect tandem with John.
It rather reminds me of the first time I read Harry Potter - how I just 
started over again, which I had never done for any book before, and the mix 
of nostalgia and enjoyment that came from rereading.
John, for continuing to inspire us and for, occasionally, rendering me as 
incomprehensibly whimsical as you -
Thank you, and DFTBA.﻿
